query: What are the ethical standards faculty should observe?
answer: "Section 355.6: They hold before them the best scholarly and ethical standards of their discipline."  "Section 355.6: Professors make every reasonable effort to foster honest academic conduct and to assure that their evaluations of students reflect each student's true merit."  "Section 355.6: Professors demonstrate respect for students as individuals and adhere to their proper roles as intellectual guides and counselors."  "Section 355.6: To this end professors devote their energies to developing and improving their scholarly competence. They accept the obligation to exercise critical self-discipline and judgment in using, extending and transmitting knowledge. They practice intellectual honesty."  "Section 355.6: As colleagues, professors have obligations that derive from common membership in the community of scholars."  "Section 355.6: Professors acknowledge academic debt and strive to be objective in their professional judgment of colleagues."  "Section 355.6: They avoid any exploitation, harassment, or discriminatory treatment of students."  "Section 355.6: As members of their community, professors have the rights and obligations of other citizens."

query: How would a faculty member conduct a faculty exchange?
answer: "A faculty member bears the burden of finding the exchanging faculty member."   "A faculty member should request approval for a proposed exchange in a written memo to his or her Department Chairman and College Dean, in which the particulars of the exchange are outlined."  "The faculty member's Department Chairman and College Dean must approve the exchange and certify that the absence of the faculty member will not curtail nor have a negative effect on the academic program."   "Upon completion of the exchange, the faculty member shall file a report with the Office of Academic Affairs detailing the experience gained during the exchange."   "A written exchange agreement, developed by the Office of Academic Affairs, will be signed by all faculty involved in the exchange and by appropriate administrative officers of the institutions."

query: What is the university stance on Academic Freedom?
answer: "Resolved: Academic freedom is the indispensable quality of institutions of higher education."  "The common good depends upon the free search for truth and its free exposition" (1940 Statement of Principles on Academic Freedom and Tenure).  "They protect their academic freedom."  "Although professors observe the stated regulations of the institution, provided the regulations do not contravene academic freedom, they maintain their right to criticize and seek revision."  "Ensure to its faculty, the rights and responsibilities of Academic Freedom, as outlined by FAM 355.6 (Statement Concerning Professional Ethics and Responsibilities)."  "As citizens engaged in a profession that depends upon freedom for its health and integrity, professors have a particular obligation to promote conditions of free inquiry and to further public understanding of academic freedom."  "Although professors may follow subsidiary interests, these interests must never seriously hamper or compromise their academic freedom or inquiry."  "Statements, reports, and policies dealing with academic freedom, as well as with other key issues, are published in the AAUP's Policy Documents and Reports, also known as the 'Redbook.'"

query: What are the ethical standards faculty should observe?
answer: "The purpose of this policy is to maintain ethical standards and define the responsibilities and accountability as faculty {Unit 3 employees of the University)."  "In accounts of their own professional activities (FARs, AARs, applications for grants and leaves and the like), faculty members are held to the same standards of honesty as they are in their professional work itself." query: How would a faculty member conduct a faculty exchange?
answer: "Faculty exchanges are normally made by two faculty members in the same department or discipline. However, an exchange between faculty of differing disciplines is permissible if appropriate arrangements are made and if no staffing problems result."  "A faculty exchange should be arranged sufficiently early in the academic year to ensure that appropriate curricular and scheduling arrangements can be made."  "Faculty exchanges are primarily for faculty who have been at an institution for an extended period of time and who would, therefore, most benefit by the renewal which may be gained from an exchange agreement."  "Thus, a faculty member bears the burden of finding the exchanging faculty member."  "Exchanges are made for a period of one academic year."  "A faculty member should request approval for a proposed exchange in a written memo to his or her Department Chairman and College Dean, in which the particulars of the exchange are outlined."  "A faculty exchange may be arranged within the CSUC system, with another private or public institution of higher learning."  "The faculty member's Department Chairman and College Dean must approve the exchange and certify that the absence of the faculty member will not curtail nor have a negative effect on the academic program."  "The exchanging faculty member coming to this campus must be acceptable to the gaining department here."  "Normal faculty appointment procedures, such as the development of a dossier and an interview, are followed in all faculty exchanges."  "Upon completion of the exchange, the faculty member shall file a report with the Office of Academic Affairs detailing the experience gained during the exchange."  "Only tenured faculty are eligible for faculty exchange, except in unusual circumstances."  "A written exchange agreement, developed by the Office of Academic Affairs, will be signed by all faculty involved in the exchange and by appropriate administrative officers of the institutions."

query: How would a faculty member conduct a faculty exchange?
answer: "A faculty member should request approval for a proposed exchange in a written memo to his or her Department Chairman and College Dean, in which the particulars of the exchange are outlined. query: What is in the faculty senate constitution?
answer: Based on the quoted sections from the FAM, here are the key elements in the Faculty Senate Constitution:  1. Structure and Membership: - Consists of elected representatives from constituent units - Officers include Chair, Vice Chair, and Executive Secretary - Includes at-large faculty representatives and representatives from other campus areas - Statewide Academic Senate delegates are voting members  2. Powers and Duties: - Acts as delegate assembly of the Faculty - Makes recommendations on University policies and operations - Establishes procedures for implementing approved policies - Keeps and distributes records of proceedings - Creates necessary committees - Reviews and revises recommendations related to University policies  3. Terms and Elections: - Members serve 2-year terms (except Statewide Senators serve 3 years and lecturers serve 1 year) - Terms are staggered with half elected each year - Officers can be removed by two-thirds vote - Each Senate serves for one academic year  4. Meeting Requirements: - Quorum requires majority of voting members - All faculty can attend but only vote if they are members - Chair presides over meetings - Executive sessions can be declared by majority vote  5. Constitutional Changes: - Reviewed every 5 years by Ad Hoc Committee - Amendments can be initiated by Senate majority or faculty petition (20%) - Adoption requires majority faculty vote  6. Committee Structure: - Standing committees make recommendations to Senate - Members elected by Senate with representation from each constituent unit - Special and ad hoc committees can be created as needed  The Constitution also outlines faculty membership qualifications, recall procedures, and the relationship with the CSU system-wide Academic Senate.

query: Tell me the steps to give a faculty member the OSRCA Award.
answer: Based on the quoted sections from the Faculty Administration Manual, here are the steps for the Outstanding Scholarship, Research, Creative Activities (OSRCA) Award:  1. "Any faculty member or academic administrator may nominate one eligible faculty member for the Outstanding Scholarship, Research, Creative Activities Award."  2. "Nominations shall be made on appropriate forms and shall include a brief statement of no more than one page explaining why the nominator believes that the faculty member merits the award."  3. "Each nomination shall be supported by the following evaluation documents:    1) the most recent Faculty Activities Reports, and     2) no more than ten documents showing the most significant accomplishments in the professional activities area as defined by the 'Procedures and Criteria for Performance Review and Periodic Evaluation.'"  4. A University Awards Committee will review the nominations "according to faculty-established criteria."  5. "While awards are typically to be given for activities actually conducted during the year for which the award is granted, work of a similar nature in prior years may be noted in the narrative and acknowledged as establishing a pattern of exceptional service."  6. "The winner shall receive an award from the Provost and the Vice President for Academic Affairs."

query: What is the university stance on Academic Freedom?
answer: Based on the quoted sections from the Faculty Administration Manual, the university's stance on Academic Freedom can be summarized through these verbatim quotes:  "Academic freedom is the indispensable quality of institutions of higher education."  "The common good depends upon the free search for truth and its free exposition."  The university views academic freedom as: - A fundamental and essential quality of higher education - Crucial for the pursuit and exposition of truth - A right that professors must protect - A responsibility that involves:   - Observing institutional regulations (unless they contravene academic freedom)   - Maintaining the right to criticize and seek revision   - Promoting conditions of free inquiry   - Furthering public understanding of academic freedom  The manual emphasizes that while professors may have subsidiary interests, "these interests must never seriously hamper or compromise their academic freedom or inquiry."  The university also notes that statements and policies on academic freedom are published in the AAUP's "Policy Documents and Reports" (the "Redbook").

query: What are the ethical standards faculty should observe?
answer: Based on the quoted sections from FAM 355.6, faculty should observe the following ethical standards:  1. Protect their academic freedom 2. Hold to the best scholarly and ethical standards of their discipline 3. Foster honest academic conduct 4. Ensure student evaluations reflect true merit 5. Demonstrate respect for students as individuals 6. Serve as intellectual guides and counselors 7. Develop and improve scholarly competence 8. Exercise critical self-discipline and judgment 9. Practice intellectual honesty 10. Acknowledge academic debt 11. Be objective in professional judgment of colleagues 12. Avoid exploitation, harassment, or discriminatory treatment of students 13. Maintain honesty in accounts of professional activities (FARs, AARs, grant applications, etc.)  If there are suspected violations of these standards, they should be reported to the Associate Provost for Faculty Affairs and Development.

query: How would a faculty member conduct a faculty exchange?
answer: Based on the quoted sections from Section 361.4, here is how a faculty member would conduct a faculty exchange:  1. "A faculty member should request approval for a proposed exchange in a written memo to his or her Department Chairman and College Dean, in which the particulars of the exchange are outlined."  2. "The faculty member bears the burden of finding the exchanging faculty member."  3. The exchange must meet certain criteria, including: - "Only tenured faculty are eligible for faculty exchange, except in unusual circumstances" - "There must be a tangible demonstration of prospects for the professional growth of the faculty member or for other benefits for this institution"  4. "The faculty member's Department Chairman and College Dean must approve the exchange and certify that the absence of the faculty member will not curtail nor have a negative effect on the academic program."  5. The exchange can be "within the CSUC system, with another private or public institution of higher learning."  6. "A written exchange agreement, developed by the Office of Academic Affairs, will be signed by all faculty involved in the exchange and by appropriate administrative officers of the institutions."  7. After the exchange, "the faculty member shall file a report with the Office of Academic Affairs detailing the experience gained during the exchange."

In order that there not be too great a disruption to a department's academic program, normally no more than 20% of the tenured faculty of any department may be on leave at any one time.  > The responsibility lies with the faculty member to initiate the exchange. The faculty member should request approval for a proposed exchange in a written memo to his or her Department Chairman and College Dean, in which the particulars of the exchange are outlined. The faculty member's Department Chairman and College Dean must approve the exchange and certify that the absence of the faculty member will not curtail nor have a negative effect on the academic program. The exchanging faculty member coming to this campus must be acceptable to the gaining department here.  > Upon completion of the exchange, the faculty member shall file a report with the Office of Academic Affairs detailing the experience gained during the exchange. Only tenured faculty are eligible for faculty exchange, except in unusual circumstances. A written exchange agreement, developed by the Office of Academic Affairs, will be signed by all faculty involved in the exchange and by appropriate administrative officers of the institutions.  > However, an exchange between faculty or differing disciplines is permissible if appropriate arrangements are made and if no staffing problems result. Appropriate Faculty Benefits, such as accrual of time toward sabbatical leave or an earned merit salary increase will be specified in the exchange agreement.

query: An ancillary unit has disbanded. What are the administrative steps to take?
answer: > Section 105.4: Upon discontinuance or termination of an Ancillary Unit, all residual funds and property become the custody of the academic unit or administrative division of the Reporting Person and shall be used for similar programs/activities that advance the mission of the campus.  > Section 105.4: Termination: An Ancillary unit may be terminated if it remains on "inactive" status for 12 months or for other compelling reasons, as determined by the Faculty Senate and the Provost/VPAA.  > Section 105.4: Inactive Status: An "inactive" Unit may not seek funding or function as an Ancillary Unit until it has undergone a successful review and has been reinstated by the Provost/VPAA.
